figure_2.title: Figure 2.
figure_2.caption: Inclusion and exclusion process applied to the study’s participant pool. From an initial 164,728 potential participants, 11,822 individuals were excluded for being below the age of 18 years, and 50,629 participants were excluded due to missing exposure data. Additionally, 5,141 participants with prior skin cancer diagnoses and 30 participants who died before the start of follow-up were excluded, resulting in 97,106 eligible participants for analysis.

claims.sentence: To ensure accurate temporal sequencing and avoid reverse causation, the follow-up period for skin cancer incidence began 6 months after the second examination (Fig. 1: T1+6 – T2).
Figure 1 provides an overview of the timeline of this study.
Furthermore, participants who died before the start of follow-up were also excluded (Fig. 2).

More information can be found on the website (https://www.lifelines-biobank.com/researchers/working-with-us).Results
Descriptive statistics
From 164,728 participants in the Lifelines cohort, the study included 97,106 individuals who met the inclusion criteria (Fig. 2).
The median time between the first and second examinations (T0 – T1) was 51.0 months (IQR: 42.00–61.00; Fig. 1).
However, changes in HbA1c, HDL, and total cholesterol were not significantly associated with skin cancer risk (Fig. 3A).
Changes in WHR, HDL, and total cholesterol were not significantly associated with skin cancer risk (Fig. 3B).

However, the other metabolic markers, including changes in HbA1c, HDL, total cholesterol, and triglycerides, were not significantly associated with skin cancer risk (Fig. 3C).Associations of changes in metabolic markers with skin cancer subtypes
The analysis of the association between changes in metabolic markers and skin cancer subtypes revealed that the results for NMSC were consistent with the overall skin cancer findings.

Other metabolic markers did not show consistent associations with skin cancer risk in this stratified analysis (Fig. 3D and E).Discussion
This study investigated how changes in metabolic markers influence skin cancer incidence.
To ensure accurate temporal sequencing and avoid reverse causation, the follow-up period for skin cancer incidence began 6 months after the second examination (Fig. 1: T1+6 – T2).
Figure 1 provides an overview of the timeline of this study.
Furthermore, participants who died before the start of follow-up were also excluded (Fig. 2).

More information can be found on the website (https://www.lifelines-biobank.com/researchers/working-with-us).Results

Results
Descriptive statistics
From 164,728 participants in the Lifelines cohort, the study included 97,106 individuals who met the inclusion criteria (Fig. 2).
The median time between the first and second examinations (T0 – T1) was 51.0 months (IQR: 42.00–61.00; Fig. 1).
However, changes in HbA1c, HDL, and total cholesterol were not significantly associated with skin cancer risk (Fig. 3A).
Changes in WHR, HDL, and total cholesterol were not significantly associated with skin cancer risk (Fig. 3B).

However, the other metabolic markers, including changes in HbA1c, HDL, total cholesterol, and triglycerides, were not significantly associated with skin cancer risk (Fig. 3C).Associations of changes in metabolic markers with skin cancer subtypes
The analysis of the association between changes in metabolic markers and skin cancer subtypes revealed that the results for NMSC were consistent with the overall skin cancer findings.
Other metabolic markers did not show consistent associations with skin cancer risk in this stratified analysis (Fig. 3D and E).
